title: Replacement Campervan Bathroom
description: No tap yet, it is on order from Go Outdoors! The sink is not hooked into the drainage either as I need a reducer to fit the 3/4" drainage piping underneath the van. The lino flooring is temporary until we find a replacement. The toilet is fully functional and fixed in position.

title: Swivel Toilet Fitted
description: The shelving unit fit without any modification. You can see the access panel is too large, this is because we moved the new toilet closer to the outside wall, as a result I had to widen the aperture. This also necessitated the removal of the traditional thetford door flap in - but we think this is no great loss. This gap will be covered with replacement wallboard - either enough for the hole or recovering the entire area behind the toilet, right of vanity unit to the wall and under the shelf.

title: IMG_8305.JPG
description: This is a splashback for our cooker and sink, required to meet the minimum required distances for combustible material (20cm). This is actually a cooker shield to stop children from reaching pots on a a hob, purchased from IKEA, we reversed it and it fits nicely.

title: IMG_8314.JPG
description: The kitchen unit. With gas oven, grill , hob and 3 way fridge

title: Bed Design v2 Proto
description: Rough drawing of the design of the bed. Essentially shows interlocking slats which when pulled out overlap slightly. The Blue section is a pull out front ad the green lines are slats fixed to the seat, purple lines are attached to the pull out front. Meanwhile the table is to be supported by both the sliding rail and the points marked with the red crosses so it is supported fully by in four corners when pulled out, these supports are marked in black and the way they sit together when closed is drawn at the bottom of the picture. Regardless of whether the bed is in 'bench' or 'bed' mode, the level of the slats should be the same height as the table sitting in the sliding rails.

title: Bed_Proto_TableMode
description:
The first bed was a temporary measure for a few journeys and sufficient for conversion on the V5. After some holidays and deciding what we needed, we came up with this design. Which reuses the table (to avoid storing a table sized bed section and uses a pullout mechanism for easy use. The bed needs to be easy and trouble free to put down as we might have been on the road all day. 

This is the bed in 'Table Mode'

title: Bed_Proto_Bench
description: This is the 2nd version of the bed in 'Bench Mode' - for three sideways facing seats. It shows the table positioned on the runners and attached to the front pull out sections. The second 'filler' panel which is hinged to the side wall is currently stowed against the wall - this should normally be hidden beneath the window and behind either the table or cushion.

title: Bed_Proto_Bed_Halfway
description: This is the 2nd version of the bed halfway between 'Table Mode' and 'Bed' mode, it shows the pull out sections, the table positioned on the runners and attached to the front pull out sections. The second 'filler' panel which is hinged to the side wall is currently being folded down - this should normally be hidden beneath the window and behind either the table or cushion.

title: Bed_Proto_Bed_Full
description: This is the 2nd version of the bed in 'Bed Mode'. The table is on the runners along with the hinged panel. The pull out sections have been pulled out revealing a complete set of bed slats. The bed has the same form factor as version 1 so the same cushions can be reused.

title: Pull Out Bed Prototype
description: Rendering of the new pull out bed layout. Coloured to show the different parts easily.

title: Original Ventilation
description: These are quite noisy fans, positioned in places to maximise the air intake and get the warm air out of the van by blowing colder air in.

title: Fan Frame
description: 120mm fans fitted to a 340mm frame which can be seated just inside the skylight.

title: Fan Seated
description: Before the flyscreen is fitted, they are checked for size. Some perspex fillers have been added to the edges of the skylight frame to help direct air through the fans and provide a better base for the aluminium frame.

title: Skylight Open, Fans Running
description: Flyscreen fitted and the wires have been fed through the roof behind the wallboard. There is enough play in the skylight frame insert to run the cables through without drilling.

title: Side Hatch with Water Access
description:
The plan was for the under seat water tank to be accessible from the outside via the side hatch. We never opted for this once things were built as there was too little room between the top of the tank and seat. So for the first version of the water system, the internal tank was filled by lifting the seat cushion and lifting a flap inside the van. We had a specific water bottle with a tap for ease of use. 
Rendered 24/6/2007

description: The tank can be accessed from inside or outside the van which is why it is up close to the wall - just off picture is an access hatch to the tank. In the end we didn't go for this option (despite the plan), the accessibility through the side hatch between the seat and the tank made it impossible.

title: Water tank rotated again

The black pipe sticking out the top is just to stop the water overflowing out of the old sub pump attachment panel. This will be replaced with a watertight seal shortly.

title: LDV Camper - Back

title: LDV Camper - Driver Side
description:
Photo taken for insurance valuation purposes. 

One decal fitted to the back, driver door decal still to be fitted but on hold until we decide what to do about side hatch which is no longer in use. The black stripe has been added to the base, the water filler is clearly visible, you can see the satellite hookup above the driver door and the solar panel on the roof.

title: LDV Camper - Passenger Side
description:
Photo taken for insurance valuation purposes. 

This shows both decals at front and back of van, a black stripe at the top and bottom of the van with a black painted trim around the side window. 

A panel van no more!

title: Daisy in the Forest
description: Stopped some way around the forest drive near Aberfoyle to take a photo of the van's paint job and decals.

title: Pitched with Sun Canopy
description: Camping Baztan, a very nice campsite! We also discovered another yellow campervan, the owner of which took photos of our camper and his together.
